div.p: 1. The current general word referring to high degree of something or intensity of the application of a predicate is shèn 甚 (ant.* post-Buddhist (NANBEICHAO) lè 略 "slightly").
2. Yǐ 已 and dà 大 refer to an extreme degree. See also EXCESSIVE
3. Zhì 至 and jí 極 refers to the ultimate or extreme high degree of something, but the meaning of jí 極 was weakened by Han times times to something like the general meaning of shèn 甚.
4. Zuì 最 refers to the largest degree or highest intensity within a given set compared. See MOST.
5. Jìng 勁 and jí 疾 add the notion of vigour to that of intensity of degree.
6. Hòu 厚 typically refers to a high degree or high intensity of something positive.
7. Zhòng 重 freely refers to an impressive intensity beyond expectation of both positive or negative qualities or actions.
8. Tòng 痛 refers specifically to a high degree of feelings or emotions.
很是 as in 很是不對
雅 (lit,obs) is a highly literary way of expressing intensity of degree.
rough draft to BEGIN TO identify synonym group members for analysis, based on CL etc. 18.11.2003. CH ／

sense.def: How true it is that S!
with redoubled intensity > more intensely than ever

entry.def: Zuì 最 refers to the largest degree or highest intensity within a given set compared. See MOST.

bibl.title: 佛經詞語匯釋 Fójīng cíyǔ huìshì The Translation of the Vocabulary of Buddhist Sūtras

sense.def: post-verbal intensifier: very, really, intensely (early examples in sūtra translations) (the V can be a complex verbal phrase) 苦痛酸切 suffering intensely (LONG AGAMA, T.1/1: 125c18) 苦切無量 suffer immeasurable (T.3/156: 152b7)

entry.def: Jìng 勁 and jí 疾 add the notion of vigour to that of intensity of degree.

sense.def: certainly; by all means; cf. modern Chinese dǎo 倒 "really" [mod CH]

entry.def: Hòu 厚 typically refers to a high degree or high intensity of something positive.

sense.def: severely, seriously; on a serious scale; wholeheartedly
figurative: serious; substantial; considerable in extent
go so far as to V
be intense; perhaps also postposed vpostadV: do this intensely

entry.def: Yǐ 已 and dà 大 refer to an extreme degree. See also EXCESSIVE

sense.def: be greater that doing so and so, be more serious than doing so and so
greatly, on a large scale (modifying a verb, the phrase again modifying a noun)
very much, mightily, highly, greatly; on a large scale

entry.def: Yǐ 已 and dà 大 refer to an extreme degree. See also EXCESSIVE

sense.def: OBI: greatly; very; to a high degree
one a furiously intense scale, on a reckless scale
V to the degree of dying > post(ad)verbial intensifier (compare 殺／煞 in this function)
intensifier preceding negated verbs: not at all, not in the least, not the slightest

note.p: 津悟福賞 deeply enlightened about merits and rewards

sense.def: especially; very; singularily; for the sole purpose

entry.def: The current general word referring to high degree of something or intensity of the application of a predicate is shèn 甚 (ant.* post-Buddhist (NANBEICHAO) lyuè 略 "slightly").

sense.def: very 甚以為苦 "consider very hard to bear".
置表甚長"put out a long advertisement"
very much, strongly; also: too much, excessively before VP: very; emphatic after VP: enormously, tremendously
甚重於王"was regarded as highly important by the king"
甚矣天下之惑也"how extreme the confusion of the world is!"
carry things far, go beyond the normal 已甚者"one who carries things too far"
be intense; be excessive, be too much; often comparative: be more intense (than), more than 太甚
怒甚 "get very angry", 醉甚"be very drunk"
more intensely than (something) 其勸甚此 "one will encourage them even more than this"
be more intense than; be stronger than 甚於
more than 悅愛之甚於王 "appreciated and loved here more than the king (did)"
overdo (something) 非甚之"critcise him for overdoing it"

entry.def: Jìng 勁 and jí 疾 add the notion of vigour to that of intensity of degree.

sense.def: be intense, be of high degree of intensity

entry.def: Tòng 痛 refers specifically to a high degree of feelings or emotions.

sense.def: deverbal intensifier before modal verbs expressing obligation: really (should); really (must); sometimes also appearing with an emphatic copula or other verbs

bibl.title: 唐五代語言詞典 Táng Wǔdài yǔyán cídiǎn A Dictionary of the Language of the Tang and Five Dynasties Periods

sense.def: colloquial intensifier: very, to a high degree (also in BIANWEN and Tang poetry)
with all one's might> powerfully, intensely
extraordinarily much, with inordinate intensity; with negations: (not) at all

entry.def: Zhì 至and jí 極 refers to the ultimate or extreme high degree of something, but the meaning of jí 極 was weakened by Han times times to something like the general meaning of shèn 甚.

sense.def: a lot, to a fair degree
a lot, to a fair degree
on an intense scale, to a pretty large extent
completely (often with negatives: not at all)

entry.def: Zhòng 重 freely refers to an impressive intensity beyond expectation of both positive or negative qualities or actions.

sense.def: be more serious than doing so and so
be intensive, be strong, be heavy; be grave
cause to become even more intense, aggravate, exacerbate
change to the bad> extreme (of illness)
by a huge margin; vastly, hugely;

bibl.title: 唐五代語言詞典 Táng Wǔdài yǔyán cídiǎn A Dictionary of the Language of the Tang and Five Dynasties Periods

note.p: 很，甚。感嘆之辭。個，詞綴。(There are also examples in Tang poetry)

sense.def: very, utterly, really (vernacular intensifier, since Tang period)
so as to cause blood flowing.
without ever getting fed up with V-ing

bibl.title: 漢語大詞典

note.p: glossed as 至極，不盡 (early examples dating from the Southern Dynasties and the Tang)

sense.def: extremely; without a limit (postposed to a V)
in the extreme, very much, inordinately
in an unheard-of way, to an unprecedented degree
in the extreme, to an "unsurpassable" degree
count as especially V; be regarded as typically V
(colloquial) suffix after verbs expressing high degree or intensity (often appearing together with intensifying adverb tài 太)
by a long shot, very much
reaching to this point> to this degree
how much more should is this true with regard to N
how much more N, by comparison
